title: 112_hr3336
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Credit Availability Act" and clarifies the definition of a swap dealer. Section 1a(49) of the Commodity Exchange Act is amended to exclude certain institutions from being considered swap dealers when entering into swaps to manage credit risk for customers or offset risks. The amendment to Section 1a(49) of the Commodity Exchange Act excludes certain institutions from being designated as swap dealers for specific types or classes of swaps, while still allowing them to enter into swaps to manage credit risk or offset risks. The amendment to the Commodity Exchange Act excludes certain swaps from being considered in determining if a person is a 'swap dealer', such as swaps for hedging commercial risk or meeting regulatory compliance purposes. The amendment to the Commodity Exchange Act excludes certain swaps, like capacity contracts, renewable energy credits, emissions allowances, or offsets, from being considered in determining if a person is a 'swap dealer' if they are used to meet state or local regulatory obligations and entered into for the person's own account. SEC. 3 amends the Commodity Exchange Act to exclude small banks, savings associations, farm credit institutions, non-profit cooperative lenders, and credit unions from the financial entity definition if their swaps exposure does not exceed $1 billion. SEC. 4 clarifies exemptions for captive finance companies from major swap participant and swap clearing requirements. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to exclude certain captive finance entities from the definition of major swap participant if their primary business is providing financing for the parent company or its subsidiaries and they use derivatives for hedging commercial risks in a consolidated portfolio. The Commodity Exchange Act excludes captive finance entities from major swap participant definition if their primary business is providing financing for the parent company or its subsidiaries, with at least 90 percent of financing being qualifying financing. Qualifying financing includes loans, notes, installment sales contracts, receivables, and operating and financing leases. The term 'product' refers to any good manufactured or sold by an affiliate of the entity, or any service provided by the entity or its affiliates. The term 'affiliate' refers to a person that reports information or prepares financial statements on behalf of an entity. A 'distribution entity' is defined as a person primarily engaged in selling, leasing, or servicing products manufactured by the entity or its affiliates. The term 'person' refers to an individual, partnership, or corporation with whom the entity or its parent company holds 50 percent or more of the equity interests. The term 'person' refers to an individual, partnership, or corporation with whom the entity or its parent company holds 50 percent or more of the equity interests. The definition of 'person' includes various entities such as corporations, limited liability companies, trusts, and government agencies. An amendment excludes certain captive finance entities from the definition of major swap participant. The amendments made by this Act will take effect as if they were part of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act. Implementation of the amendments to the Commodity Exchange Act will be done without certain provisions, through an interim final rule with public comment sought before issuing a final rule, and will only apply to changes directly related to the amendments. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 25, 2012. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
